name: the modernist magazine issue #9 DINKY
description:
* Available end of November 2013*

Contents:

Suburbia in a box - Hannah Neate

‘Cinquecento...’ - Stephen Hale 

So it goes  - Angela Connolly 

Minimum dwelling Maximum being - Ben Tallis 

From a Jack to an Ace - Matthew Steele 

Beep Beep!  - Aidan Turner Bishop

Prefab - Eddy Rhead 

Stamps  - Joe Austin

Piccola Roma  - William Parnell

From bold to belligerent  - Richard Brook 

Nakagin  - Filipe Magalhaes and Ana Luisa Soares 

—
Reviews 

Warsaw Modern, Kristin Mosjsiewicz
 
Architecture on the Carpet, Natalie Bradbury

name: Metro Modern Map
description:
Metro Modern, our new map & guide to Manchester's Twentieth Century Architecture.

With the help of our handy guide you will be able to tour central Manchester by foot or on a free Metro Shuttle Bus - all our buildings are within a short hop of Manchester's three Metro Shuttle Bus routes.

Maps are free and available for just the price of the postage.

(Available from 26.10.13)

With special thanks to the Heritage Lottery Fund

options.name: With donation to support the Society's future work

name: SUBSCRIBE NOW! - 4 future issues
description:
the modernist - (4 x issues)

a new design for our third year!

delivered direct to your door with discounted postage for annual subscribers

*if you become a Manchester Modernist Member - you will be entitled to a 10% discount on subscription plus other benefits

If you're the old fashioned type who likes to use a cheque or postal order, please post your order to:

manchester modernist society
manchester house
86 princess street
manchester
m1 6ng

options.name: From issue 9 -Discount for paid Members only

name: the modernist magazine issue #8 CARRIED AWAY
description:
Contents

Velvet Underground - Ben Tallis under the surface of Prague 

Brrrmm To Brum - Aidan Turner Bishop is on a bus trip to Birmingham

I Like It Here - Mikey Georgeson loves a good service station

Meet Me At The Monorail - Joe Austin travels in the future

Travelling In Style: The Ss Oriana - Robert Griffiths on board the last liner from Barrow 

Pier Head - Matthew Whitfield misses the bus

Spirited Away - Jessica Holland - is it a school.. or is it an aeroplane?

For All The Right Reasons - Richard Brook goes to Oldham

Dun Movin'- Angela Connelly & Matthew Steele move to Cumberanuld

The World Geo-Graphic Atlas - Eddy Rhead globe trots with Bayer's atlas

The Racic Mausoleum – Carol Hardie visits the dead

This Station Is Delayed - Josh Abbott takes the Central Line

Review - Eddy Rhead

name: the modernist magazine issue #7 CAPITAL
description:
Sound Capitol: listen to EMI's sound capital with Robert Griffiths 

Capital B | Capital R: William Parnall looks forward to the age of the train

Eternal City / Modern City: Stephen Hale yearns for a Roman Holiday

Green, free and modern: Aidan Turner-Bishop on early Irish modernism.

Shooting the Moon: Tom Brooks beams a message from the South Bank

The Continuation of Warsaw by Other Means: Benjamin Tallis

Capital Transfer: Jack Hale on the Guardian, George Best and the missing Whitehall of the North

Strength Through Adversity: Jo Austin in Argentina

Scotland’s Unité: DoCoMoMo Scotland's Clive Fenton on Edinburgh's Unité

Herbert Bayer: creating capital, rejecting capitals by Emily Gee

Ex Press – Eddy Rhead searches for a lost Newspaper Capital

Berlin, Capital of a Country That No Longer Exists: Honor Gavin and Richard Martin 

Century of the Child – review – Natalie Bradbury

name: the modernist magazine issue #5 CAMPUS
description:
the modernist issue #5

Out end of August 2012

Aidan Turner Bishop reminisces on library Life in the Tropics

The Decorated School: Natalie Bradbury on the recent re-evaluation of art in post-war schools

Gud With Buildings: Phil Griffin on the evolution of the Co-op’s Manchester HQ

Richard Martin explores Campo Gulbenkian, Lisbon’s green modernist wonderland

Hidden Cambridge: Marco Iuliano rediscovers Le Corbusier in Cambridge

Richard Brook on UMIST & the Evolution of an Technological Institution

Stephen Hale: When a student generation plumped for Plateglass over Red Brick?

Forgotten But Not Gone:  Joshua Abbott remembers Middlesex Modernists Curtis and Burchett

Oblique Dysfunction:  Steve Millington on Montreal’s Olympic torture

Robert Griffiths investigates why Barrow built The Finest Women’s Institute in the Country

Concrete Schoolyard: Benjamin Tallis’s ode to collectivism and the communist Panel House

Ian Tocher encounters Yamasaki’s distinctive Detroit campus

Jack Hale admires a most Modern Symbol for the ‘University of the Air’

(Mag image by by Claire Solanki)

name: the modernist archive
description:
ISSN 2046-2905

Four issues of the modernist magazine in one sturdy cardboard archive box.. corr!

Issues #5 to #8: Campus, Cuppa, Capital & Carried Away all together in this strictly limited archive boxed set.

This is limited to no more than 20 sets -  we just don't have enough copies to make more!

This really is the last chance to get all four issues of the modernist volume #2 together all in one go.

Go on - its nearly Christmas...

name: Membership Donation - Manchester Modernist Society
description:
Manchester Modernist Society Honorary Membership


Support the Manchester Modernist Society with a donation of £10.00 and we'll make you an Honorary Member!

The Manchester Modernist Society is a not for profit voluntary organisation that educates and inspires people about the built environment of the 20th Century in Greater Manchester.

You can help sustain our work by becoming an Honorary Member.
valid until end of year*: £10.00

Benefits:

You will receive:
•	our beautiful enamel members badge 
•	10% discount on annual subscription of our quarterly Modernist Magazine via our web shop
•	10% discount on all Modernist Society publications via our web shop
•	10% discount on any charged Society events
•	Invitations to all our project, magazine and event launches
•	Priority booking on all our events
•	Monthly e-mail updates and news

*N.B.The current membership year runs to 30th June 2014

www.manchestermodernistsociety.org/

If you're the old fashioned type who likes to use a cheque or postal order, please post your order to:

manchester modernist society
manchester house
86 princess street
manchester
m1 6ng

name: Toasting the Toastrack - greetings cards
description:
Four greetings cards celebrating Manchester's favourite Toastrack shaped building.

Published as part of the Manchester Modernist Society creative residency at MMU's Hollings Faculty aka The Toastrack, we give you...

Fashion-rack: 1950s students and staff in quite absurd outfits, with  the part constructed Toastrack in the background.

Bikini-rack: Four be-suited Toastrack chaps take the measure of one bikini clad girl.

Guitar-rack: Hip Toastrack students from the 1960s with guitar and groovy shades.

Roof-rack: Three 1970s fashion students in floaty dresses on the Toastrack roof.

£2.50 individually or £8.75 for a pack of all four.

15 x 15cm blank inside with white envelope in cellophane wrap.

Special thanks to John Williams for his Guitar-rack and Bikini-rack images - see more of John's Toastrack work here:

thetoastrack.wordpress.com/2013/04/23/looking-in/

name: Preston By-pass
description:
A souvenir brochure reprinted to celebrate the 50th anniversary of the official opening of Britain's first Motorway the Preston By-pass.

Opened on the 5th of December 1958 this is a glossy 24 brochure highlighting all the fun.

name: Toastrack / Hollings Postcard
description:
Vintage Postcard featuring Manchester's much loved 'Toastrack'. 

In August 2013, as Manchester Metropolitan University prepare to leave the building for the last time.. we offer you a glimpse of its heyday as the star of an "All British Production Dennis Postcard".

name: the modernist magazine issue #6 CUPPA
description:
Modernist Issue #6 (Out December 2012)
Cuppa

Contents: 

Due Esspressi : take a coffee or two and imbibe the Italian influence with Aidan Turner Bishop

The ever scholarly Dr. Matthew Whitfield hangs around in the Library Cafe

Indecent Exposure : in Prague with Ben Tallis 

Meiner ist größer als deiner: Billy Butlin’s Secret Revolution - Jack Hale takes a turn.

Maureen Ward polishes up her favorite spoon : David Mellor and a design called Thrift 

Liverpool Resurgent : Kenn Taylor sups in a hidden Liverpool Cafe

Joe Austin takes Tea & Cakes Under an Umbrella Sky

Café view 51-61-71 - Lucas Nightingale in a Canadian coffee mood

No ceramic cups for Gemma Galgani in Modernism, immortality and Melamine

Holidaying as Social Revolution with Robert Griffiths

Cars and Cafes – A Sam Scorer trip alongside Ian Tocher

Howitt's Domestic Goddess - the biggest Toast Rack in the world!

name: Road Sign pin badges
description:
Oh, my - a gorgeous mixed set of three vintage Dutch Road Sign pin badges imported especially for your delight. Pin 'em on your hat or use them on your Scalextric track - up to you.

(plastic badge with metal pin - be warned its a sharp one! three badges will be selected for you at random)

name: 'No Rubbish Tipped Here' (4 postcards)
description:
For the Secret Gardens Festival 2012, a set of four postcards illustrating pre-generated urban spaces which acted as alternative gardens and unlikely playgrounds for a generation of Salfordians.

Photos by kind permission of John Travis of Salford

name: Salford Pin badges - set of 3
description: A set of three pin badges celebrating the delights of Salford by Salford's own Mr.P.S.

name: Manchester Piccadilly (4 postcards)
description:
A set of four postcards celebrating Manchester's brutalist heart   - Piccadilly Plaza. Each set contains an image of 'gone but not forgotten' Bernard House, with its Thunderbird flyaway roof, Sunley Tower, Piccadilly Ice Cream Van and a hardy Piccadilly Pigeon. Each comes in a specially embossed 'glassine' packet.

The images were selected form the archive of our favourite documentor of Manchester, photographer Jan Chlebik.

name: Photographs of Manchester Book
description: By Jan Chlebik. paperback edition 17x24.5cm 64 pages

name: the modernist issue #3 'BOOM & BUST'
description:
the modernist issue #3

Out mid December 2011.

owen hatherley on why an eye on the past is more than mere nostalgia

as salford’s media city warms up its valves, eddy rhead reminds us how to broadcast ‘from the north’

sands of time – liverpool’s defunct emblem to a long lost corporate largesse

aidan turner bishop ponders the rise and fall of hornsea pottery

natalie bradbury on northern sixties film without the kitchen sink drama...

the mysterious case of the liverpool garden festival; dan russell investigates

morag rose’s modernist guide to a w.a.g-free essex

holidays in utopia - ben tallis on the many lives of st leninsburg

stephen hale drives the futurist fiat test-track

christien garcia reports from edmonton, capital of canada’s big oil province...

reviews: all in a days work - the modernist watches tom cordell’s utopia london, and visits the R.A.’s new exhibition building the revolution

name: Granada TV Centre
description:
'From the North' - a laser cut model of the fabulous Granada TV studios.

(20cm x 5cm x 4cm aprox)

Ready made - or Flat Pack pop out version!
